pullRequest.title: ClassFileOracle changes to adopt OpenJDK MethodHandles and VarHandles
pullRequest.bodyText:
For the OpenJDK MethodHandles (MHs), MH.invoke and MH.invokeExact have the
same behavior. So, MH.invoke and MH.invokeExact are translated to the
same bytecode, invokehandle. Then, invokehandlegeneric becomes unused.


For the OpenJDK implementation, the invokevirtual calls to the VarHandle
polymorphic methods are also translated to the invokehandle bytecode.


The OpenJDK MH/VH implementation relies upon LambdaForms to dynamically
generate bytecodes on the Java side. So, operations such as asType are handled
on the Java side. This allows MH.invoke, MH.invokeExact and VH polymorphic
methods to share a common path in the interpreter.


A new utility function, VM_VMHelpers::isPolymorphicVarHandleMethod, has
been added to check for polymorphic VarHandle methods, and the associated
redundant code has been removed.


Related: #7352
Co-authored-by: Jack Lu Jack.S.Lu@ibm.com
Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh sbabneet@ca.ibm.com

nodes.bodyText:
There's a very similar method in ConstantPoolMap that determines if a cpEntry is for a VarHandle method.  Is it possible to reuse the existing method - ConstantPoolMap::isVarHandleMethod - or share the list between the two methods?
Duplicating these kinds of lists leads to one getting out of sync.
If the long term goal is to remove the other list, then adding comments to both lists referencing the other would help with short term maintenance.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2375,6 +2375,112 @@ ClassFileOracle::methodIsNonStaticNonAbstract(U_16 methodIndex)
 	return J9_ARE_NO_BITS_SET(_classFile->methods[methodIndex].accessFlags, (CFR_ACC_STATIC | CFR_ACC_ABSTRACT));
 }
 
+#if defined(J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE)
+/**
+ * Determine if the method name corresponds to a VarHandle method with polymorphic
+ * signature.
+ *
+ * @param methodName the constant pool info for the method name
+ *
+ * @return true for a VarHandle method with polymorphic signature. Otherwise,
+ * return false.
+ */
+bool
+ClassFileOracle::isPolymorphicVarHandleMethod(J9CfrConstantPoolInfo *methodName)

beforeCommit.message:
Rewrite VarHandle polymorphic methods to invokehandle bytecode

For the OpenJDK implementation, the VarHandle polymorphic methods are
translated to the invokehandle bytecode.

For the OpenJ9 implementation, the VarHandle polymorphic methods are
redirected to the invokevarhandle INL during resolution.

Co-authored-by: Jack Lu <Jack.S.Lu@ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

afterCommit.message:
Consolidate code for checking a VarHandle polymorphic method

There are three locations where redundant code is used to check if a
class method is a VarHandle polymorphic method. The three locations are
the following:
1) initsendtarget.cpp::initializeMethodRunAddressVarHandle
2) ConstantPoolMap::isVarHandleMethod
3) ClassFileOracle::isPolymorphicVarHandleMethod

A new utility function, VM_VMHelpers::isPolymorphicVarHandleMethod, has
been added to support the above three locations.

The redundant code has been removed, and the new utility function is
being used in the above three locations.

Co-authored-by: Jack Lu <Jack.S.Lu@ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

nodes.bodyText:
Don't change this =)  The change isn't required and the original formatting kept the if and its conditions lined up with the opening brace.  Easier to track with your eye then indenting.

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            			|| (J9CPTYPE_INTERFACE_INSTANCE_METHOD == _romConstantPoolTypes[i])
          
          
            
            		|| (J9CPTYPE_INTERFACE_INSTANCE_METHOD == _romConstantPoolTypes[i])

This can be moved into the if ((sizeof(VARHANDLE_CLASS_NAME) - 1) == classNameLength) { block - always aim for the shortest lifetime for variables as possible as it makes reasoning about the code simpler

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1728,6 +1729,120 @@ class VM_VMHelpers
 		return rc;
 	}
 
+	/**
+	 * Determine if the method name corresponds to a VarHandle method with polymorphic
+	 * signature.
+	 *
+	 * @param methodNameData the bytes of the method name
+	 * @param methodNameLength the length of the method name
+	 *
+	 * @return true for a VarHandle method with polymorphic signature. Otherwise,
+	 * return false.
+	 */
+	static VMINLINE bool
+	isPolymorphicVarHandleMethod(const U_8 *methodNameData, U_32 methodNameLength)
+	{
+		bool result = false;
+
+		switch (methodNameLength) {
+		case 3:
+			if ((0 == memcmp(methodNameData, "get", methodNameLength))
+				|| (0 == memcmp(methodNameData, "set", methodNameLength))
+			) {

commit.message:
Rewrite MH.invoke and MH.invokeExact to invokehandle for OpenJDK MHs

For OpenJDK MethodHandles (MHs), MH.invoke and MH.invokeExact have the
same behavior. So, MH.invoke and MH.invokeExact are translated to the
same bytecode, "invokehandle".

The OpenJDK MH implementation relies upon LambdaForm(s) to dynamically
generate bytecodes on the Java side. So, operations such as asType are
handled on the Java side. This allows MH.invoke/invokeExact to share a
common path in the interpreter.

For OpenJ9 MHs, MH.invoke is translated to the invokehandlegeneric
bytecode, and MH.invokeExact is translated to the invokehandle bytecode.

Co-authored-by: Jack Lu <Jack.S.Lu@ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

Rewrite VarHandle polymorphic methods to invokehandle bytecode

For the OpenJDK implementation, the VarHandle polymorphic methods are
translated to the invokehandle bytecode.

The OpenJDK MH/VH implementation relies upon LambdaForm(s) to
dynamically generate bytecodes on the Java side. So, operations such as
asType are handled on the Java side. This allows MH.invoke,
MH.invokeExact and VH polymorphic methods to share a common path in the
interpreter.

For the OpenJ9 implementation, the VarHandle polymorphic methods are
redirected to the invokevarhandle INL during resolution.

Co-authored-by: Jack Lu <Jack.S.Lu@ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

Consolidate code for checking a VarHandle polymorphic method

There are two locations where redundant code is used to check if a
class method is a VarHandle polymorphic method. The two locations are
the following:
1) ConstantPoolMap::isVarHandleMethod
2) ClassFileOracle::isPolymorphicVarHandleMethod

A new utility function, VM_VMHelpers::isPolymorphicVarHandleMethod, has
been added to support the above two locations.

The redundant code has been removed, and the new utility function is
being used in the above two locations.

Co-authored-by: Jack Lu <Jack.S.Lu@ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>
